awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: FishLife: genealogy and traits of living and fossil vertebrates that never left the water
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop and apply a unified framework for studying the evolution of all fishes, including lampreys, sharks, and the coral reef, deep sea and freshwater fishes. This work will illuminate the genealogical relationships (phylogeny), evolutionary timing, and mechanisms for the origin and maintenance of the world's diversity of fishes, including the most important food and aquarium fishes. The project will contribute to community-driven scientific efforts, to student training, to web content and application development, and to public outreach. All fish specimens, specimen and DNA data, and analytical results obtained will be made publicly available through a dynamic and open structure that complies with established standards to facilitate wide accessibility to the broader scientific and non-scientific communities. High school, undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral student training are central activities for this project. Social media outreach and training will provide diverse professional development opportunities as well. A fish species identification application for smartphones based on image data (FishSnap) will be developed and made freely available to the public to allow accurate identification of selected groups of fishes. Outcomes of this project will form part of a new public exhibit at the National Museum of Natural History to highlight the value of specimen collections at natural history museums.

This integrative project will combine genomic, paleontological, anatomical, functional, ecological, and comparative approaches. The research team blends strengths in collections-based research on fishes, molecular and morphological phylogenetics, bioinformatics, and comparative analyses, allowing them to synthesize big data sets to resolve the phylogeny of all described fish species and conduct evolutionary analysis of key traits. Time-calibrated trees will be used to reveal diversification patterns of the major groups. Image analysis, morphometrics, and phenomic data will enable the discovery of evolutionary patterns in size, shape, and biomechanical function across thousands of species.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
I. Intellectual Merit:

The FishLife project, supported by NSF grants DEB-1541491 and DEB-1932759, embarked on a monumental journey to enhance our understanding of the Fish Tree of Life. In a collaborative effort among researchers of five institutions, the project utilized genomic and anatomical data from both fossil and living fish species to construct comprehensive trees, while collecting traits, geographical, and ecological data to advance our knowledge of fish macroevolution. The proposed set of exon markers, designed and optimized for fish phylogenomics, is poised to become a valuable public resource for future studies. Moreover, FishLife demonstrated a strong commitment to education, outreach, student training and public engagement, ensuring that the knowledge generated remains a source of inspiration for curiosity and exploration in the broader community. The collaborative nature of the project positions FishLife as a transformative initiative in the ongoing quest to complete the Tree of Life for fishes.

The intellectual merit of the project is underscored by its groundbreaking contributions to our understanding of the evolutionary relationships among fishes. Among the 38 scientific papers produced by the Betancur lab, several key outcomes demonstrate the project's significance.

  1. Phylogenomics Reveals the Deep Ocean as an Accelerator for Evolutionary Diversification: This study is currently accepted for publication in Nature Ecology and Evolution (Miller et al., 2024). It explores the deep ocean as a catalyst for evolutionary diversification in anglerfishes. The findings may provide crucial insights into the factors influencing speciation in deep-sea environments.
  2. Phylogenomic Analysis of Flatfish Asymmetry: A notable achievement is the acceptance, with revision, of a paper in Nature Genetics (Duarte-Ribeiro et al., 2024). Contrary to the findings of another paper published in the same journal in 2021, our work supports a single evolutionary origin of flatfish asymmetry using phylogenomic and comparative genomic analyses. See Figure 1.
  3. Impact of Paleoclimatic Changes on Body Size Evolution: The project explored the influence of paleoclimatic changes on body size evolution in marine fishes, leading to a publication in PNAS (Troyer et al., 2022). This research provides insights into how environmental factors, specifically climatic shifts, influence the evolution of body size in marine fish populations. See Figure 2.
  4. Phylogenomics and Historical Biogeography of Seahorses and Allies: Two studies on seahorses, dragonets, goatfishes, and allies, one published (Santaquiteria et al., 2021 Sys. Bio.) and one under review, delve into the historical biogeography of these carismatic fishes. The studies assesses biogeography, lineage diversification and morphological evolution, contributing to our understanding of the distribution and evolution of these marine species. See Figure 3.
  5. Evolutionary Determinism and Convergence in Marine Fishes: Another impactful publication in PNAS (Rincon-Sandoval et al., 2020) explores evolutionary determinism and convergence associated with water-column transitions in marine fishes. This research reveals insights into the evolutionary forces driving adaptations related to changes in the water column. See Figure 4. 
  6. Bioinformatics Advances for Fish Phylogenomics: A series of four papers (Arcila et al., 2017; Hughes et al., 2018, 2020, 2021) detail the molecular methods and bioinformatic pipelines developed by the FishLife team. These contributions lay the groundwork for assembling phylogenomic datasets and resolving phylogenetic relationships among all fishes, a monumental task that the project is on the brink of accomplishing. See Figure 5.
  7. Comprehensive Phylogeny of Ray-Finned Fishes: A comprehensive phylogeny of ray-finned fishes, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (Hughes et al., 2018), provides a foundational understanding of the evolutionary relationships within this diverse group of fishes. This work, based on transcriptomic and genomic data, contributes to our broader understanding of fish evolution.
  8. Phylogenetic Classification of Bony Fishes: The FishLife team's efforts culminated in a phylogenetic classification of bony fishes (Betancur-R. et al., 2017) published in BMC Evolutionary Biology. This classification provides a framework for understanding the evolutionary relationships among bony fishes – a crucial step in completing the Tree of Life. See Figure 6.
  9. Genome-Wide Interrogation Advances Resolution in the Tree of Life (Arcila et al. 2017; Nature Ecology & Evolution): This paper includes the first published dataset for ostariophysan fishes and the introduces a novel approach, which we named "Gene Genealogy Interrogation", to enhance our ability to resolve complex relationships within the Tree of Life.

 

II. Broader Impacts:

The FishLife project has extended its impact far beyond the realm of scientific publications, actively engaging with communities of interest and fostering opportunities for training and professional development. Dissemination of Results:In addition to the 38 scientific papers, the project team actively participated in scientific conferences, including the Evolution Meeting and the Joint Meeting of Ichthyologists and Herpetologists. Through presentations and posters, the team shared their findings with the global scientific community, promoting dialogue and collaboration. Training and Professional Development: The FishLife project prioritized training and professional development, with graduate students and postdocs playing a central role. Two undergraduate students also conducted honors thesis research, contributing to their academic and professional development.


Last Modified: 02/05/2024
Modified by: Ricardo Betancur

Images (1 of )
  • Phylogeny, biogeographic history, regional speciation rate and lineages through time of Seahorses, dragonets, goatfishes, and allies (Syngnatharia). Santaquiteria et al. (under review); Santaquiteria et al. (2021; Systematic Biology).
    A. Santaquiteria
    Copyrighted
    Ricardo Betancur
    Figure 3
  • Probe sets designed to capture and sequence 1,105 exons for fish phylogenomics using target enrichment approaches. Seven probe sets were designed and tested (five are shown in the phylogenetic tree depicted). From Hughes et al. (2020; Molecular Ecology Resources).
    L. Hughes
    Copyrighted
    Ricardo Betancur
    Figure 5
  • Phylogenetic classification of bony fishes � a major product of the award. From Betancur-R. et al. (2017; BMC Evolutionary Biology).
    R. Betancur-R.
    Copyrighted
    Ricardo Betancur
    Figure 6
  • Figure 1. Phylogenomic analyses support a single evolutionary origin of the asymmetric body plan of flatfishes. FM: flatfish monophyly ? i.e., single asymmetry origin; FP: flatfish monophyly ? i.e., dual asymmetry origin. From Ribeiro et al. (accepted; Nature Genetics).
    E. Ribeiro
    Copyrighted
    Ricardo Betancur
    Figure 1
  • Evolution of tetraodontiform body size over time, including superfamily Plectocretacicoidea. The estimated ancestral body size of tetraodontiforms is two to three times smaller than the mean of present-day taxa, supporting both Cope?s and Bergmann?s rules From Troyer et al. (2022; PNAS).
    E. Troyer
    Public Domain
    Ricardo Betancur
    Figure 2
  • Phylogenomics and biogeography of snappers and fusiliers (Lutjanidae), highlighting the recurrent evolution of deep-bodied benthic species and pelagic species with streamlined body plans. The study emphasizes strong evolutionary determinism in form and function along the benthic?pelagic axis.
    M. Rincon & E. Ribeiro
    Copyrighted
    Ricardo Betancur
    Figure 4
